@@8393230 <p> Cherries usually hit ... market in late April , but in Lleida the season kicks off earlier than anywhere else in the world . The fruit there goes on sale in mid-March , which is when the harvest starts in the greenhouses that the company SAT Edoa has in the towns of Almacelles and Sucs . <p> In two plots with five hectares each , the firm 's four partners annually grow about 40,000 kilos of cherries . Only a small share of them remains in Spanish territory , as 80% of the production is exported to the UK , the UAE and France . A few days ago , in Paris , the singer Madonna bought 15 kilos of this unique product . The rest of the production is shipped to Barcelona and Madrid . <p> Lleida 's climate is the key . " Because of the temperatures recorded these days in the area , the trees within the facilities are tricked into behaving as they would in May , " explains Eduard Rosell , director of R&amp;D at the company . The greenhouses are able to stay between five and six degrees at night and go up to 25 during the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ areas . <p> These cherries , known in the market as Cherries Glamour , stand out for their dark red colour and large size , which can reach up to 34 millimetres in diameter , larger than a 2 Euro coin . " The largest have to be eaten in two bites , it is not enough with one , " jokes Rosell . <p> 125 Euro per kilo <p> The Cherries Glamour are the earliest cherries in the market , but also the most expensive . The largest and reddest can cost up to 125 Euro per kilo . " And people buy them , " assures Rosell . They are not sold in large boxes ; the company has designed baskets of different sizes , ranging between 100 grams and one kilo and a half , so that consumers can taste them without having to spend their whole salaries . <p> In any case , there are also cheaper ones . The company 's partners estimate that the average price this year will stand at 50 Euro per kilo . Production in 2016 will reach about 40,000 kilos @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ count on getting a turnover of around two million Euro . <p> The promoters of this project , which was launched in 2000 as a hobby , but became their main source of income four years later , found a niche market for this product , because the cherry harvest in the southern hemisphere came to a close in February and in the northern hemisphere it did not start until late April . Therefore , they decided to go all in on this project and supply cherries when there were none available . They even managed to leave the label " greenhouse fruit " behind . 
@@8393231 <p> According to the ... Central Bank , " fruit and vegetable prices in March have fallen compared to February for the first time since records have been kept ( by 1.3 percent ) . Compared with March last year , fruit and vegetables were worth an average of 5.1 percent less , " reported the statement . <p> To explain these lower prices , the body has named a number of temporary factors , including the high volume of deals in the domestic food market , the downward trend in world prices for agricultural products and the favourable forecasts for the harvest in Russia and the world . <p> It is worth noting that , on 22 March , Russia started receiving the first shipments of Syrian fruit and vegetables , which should have served to partially replace banned Turkish imports . 
@@8393232 <p> This week ( ... 17th to 23rd ) is National Soil Conservation Week in Canada , and as potato farmers across Prince Edward Island are gearing up for spring planting , they are making soil conservation a priority on their farms . <p> According to the Prince Edward Island Soil and Crop Improvement Association , 2016 is the thirtieth year of concentrated efforts by farmers and government to protect our valuable soils through programs that fund the construction of soil conservation structures such as terraces , berms and grassed waterways . Additionally , promotion of beneficial practices such as strip cropping , winter cover cropping , residue management , and retirement of sensitive land have all been essential to preventing the erosion of rich topsoil from farmers ? fields . <p> The Prince Edward Island Potato Board enthusiastically supports all initiatives aimed at promoting soil conservation , thereby preserving the productivity of Island fields and preventing the degradation of Island waterways . A number of PEI potato farmers work with their local watershed associations on collaborative projects to prevent soil erosion and improve local watersheds , and many potato farmers have invested in soil conservation measures on their farms . <p> According to @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Potato Board , ? Potato farmers recognize that it is essential to conserve soil and build soil quality to ensure the economic and environmental sustainability of our industry . In addition , the industry is funding research being conducted by Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada into the further use of fall cover crops , spring nurse crops , and residue tillage to prevent soil erosion and promote soil health . ? <p> A large number of Island farmers are expanding their efforts to enhance soil conservation and soil health . Among them are Darren and Brenda Peters of Maple Plains , who were recognized earlier this year with a 2016 Soil Conservation Award from the PEI Soil and Crop Improvement Association for their efforts to conserve and improve the soils on their farm . Additionally , the Hogg Family of Klondike Farms in Wilmot Valley was recognized with the PEI Federation of Agriculture ? s 2016 Gilbert Clements Award for Sustainable Agriculture in no small part due to their efforts to prevent soil erosion and improve soil health in their fields . <p> Potato farmers have many partners to thank that @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , including the PEI Soil and Crop Improvement Association , the PEI Department of Agriculture and Fisheries , Agriculture &amp; Agri-Food Canada , and local watershed groups working together with farmers for the betterment of the industry and the environment . 
@@8393234 <p> Vegetable and fruit ... have jumped over the past month in the Kathmandu Valley as production has dropped sharply with the onset of the dry season . <p> Mustard leaves , potato , fenugreek leaves and local cauliflower have become costlier as deliveries have fallen . A drop in shipments has put upward pressure on prices of popular vegetables , officials of the Kalimati Fruits and Vegetable Market said . <p> ? Production usually declines during the dry season causing significant changes in prices , ? said Manoj Dhital , senior market officer at the Kalimati Fruits and Vegetable Market Development Board . <p> On Monday , local vendors were selling cauliflower at Rs75-85 per kg against Rs45 last month . Likewise , retail prices of red potato , fenugreek leaves and mustard leaves jumped 28.57 percent , 81.39 percent and 105.26 percent respectively over the past month . <p> Because of a significant drop in supply , almost all leafy vegetables like mustard greens , spinach , fenugreek leaves and garden cress saw an increase in retail prices by 80 to 100 percent , according to the board . Traders said that supplies had been hit hard by the dry season and @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ a little rain which had affected production . <p> ? Farmers in Kathmandu , Bhaktapur , Lalitpur , Dhading and Nuwakot have cut deliveries of leafy vegetables leading to a hike in prices , ? said Bharat Khatiwada , a fresh vegetable trader at the Kalimati market . ? The supply of essentials like tomato and potato is stable , but other vegetables are seeing a drop in shipments. ? <p> According to Khatiwada , a supply of more than 1,000 tonnes can lead to a drop in prices and fulfil the valley ? s daily requirement . However , shipments currently amount to 500 tonnes . <p> ? Farmers in the main growing areas have been hit hard by last year ? s earthquake , and they have not been able to reach their optimum production level . This has also affected supplies . Farmers in other hilly areas have been hit hard by drought. ? Meanwhile , popular summer fruits like pineapple , cucumber and carrot have also become dearer by Rs30 , Rs15 and Rs50 per kg respectively . <p> The Kalimati and Balkhu markets account for @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ valley .

@@8461238 <h> Former AP boss ... Kaunya returns from exile , given hero 's welcome <p> Former senior AP officer Oku Kaunya has returned from exile , where he fled at the start of the cases against six Kenyans by the ICC . <p> Kaunya was given a hero 's welcome yesterday . <p> He and his family went into exile in 2010 after they expressed fears for their lives . <p> In December 2007 , he was the Deputy Commandant of the Administration Police and Commandant of the AP Training College in Embakasi . He had originally been scheduled to take over from AP Commandant Kinuthia Mbugua in 2008 . <p> It was alleged that the Administration Police was partly responsible for the mayhem that followed the December 2007 elections . <p> Kaunya left Kenya in April 2010 . It had been rumoured that he will be a key witness for ICC prosecutor Luis Moreno Ocampo . <p> After receiving death threats from unknown people , Kaunya slipped out of Kenya in April claiming he needed medical treatment for a kidney problem . His whereabouts remained unknown until his sudden return . <p> Kaunya headed the AP Training College which , according to the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of the December 2007 election . <p> An appeal by his father Francis Masai in 2012 to retired President Kibaki to accord his son security before a return home failed to bear fruit . <p> Kaunya travelled home to join relatives and friends in marking his father 's 92nd birthday at Kakemer Primary School in Busia . <p> " I know everybody prayed for me when I fled the country since my life was in danger . God is my protector . I am here today because of my God . He could be having a reason for my six-years of suffering , " he said . <p> " God had specific plans for me when I fled the country , leaving behind my wife Millicent . I thank God my children are okay abroad . East or West , home is best . My heart still feels home , " he said . <p> Kaunya thanked his father , the Governor and others for their effort in appealing for his security to enable him to return home . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ <h> IPP to focus

" MicroStrategy Incorporated , a leading worldwide provider of business intelligence software , today announced that GT Nexus has selected MicroStrategy to power the customer-facing analytics and reporting capabilities on its Global Logistics portal . The GT Nexus portal is an on demand technology platform that is used by importers , exporters , transportation carriers , suppliers , banks , and other partners to manage goods that are moving around the world . The GT Nexus system captures and stores hard-to-get data associated with global supply chains , and then fuels a range of Web applications that can be used by constituents to lower supply chain costs and improve control . Kara said public spaces are under great threat from individuals keen on using such spaces for selfish commercial interests and blamed it to poor planning , corruption , non-enforcement of laws and uncoordinated constructions . PHOTO/Hivisasa.com <p> The Kenya Alliance of Resident Associations ( Kara ) says it has received numerous cases from its members regarding land grabbing or misuse of public spaces . <p> According to Kara Chief Executive Officer Henry Ochieng ' , public spaces such as children playgrounds , community centres , parks and high streets play a vital role in the social life of communities . <p> " They are the setting for a multitude of activities such as festivals , trade , the movement of goods and people , community life and livelihoods . They are multi-functional areas that should be properly designed and managed to promote cultural activities and build peaceful and democratic societies . " <p> In Kenya and particularly urban areas , Kara said public spaces are under great threat from individuals keen on using such spaces for selfish commercial interests and blamed it to poor planning , corruption , non-enforcement of laws and uncoordinated constructions @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ spaces meant for social amenities is common place in most neighborhoods . It is becoming increasingly common to walk into an estate and find children risking their lives by playing on the estate roads because there are no open playing spaces for them . What is more disheartening is that there are Government officers who are colluding with unscrupulous developers to circumvent laws and policies that are meant to protect such spaces , " Ochieng ' said . <p> To curb this , the Alliance is working with the National Land Commission ( NLC ) and other relevant government agencies to ensure that the spaces revert to the community and put to proper use . <p> Ochieng ' said Kenya needs to put more effort in the design , management and protection of its public spaces , including developing strong polices and laws specifically designed to protect such spaces from misuse or grabbing . <p> " Emphasis should be placed on effective enforcement of the policies and laws . @@8943235 <h> Let 's not ... the logistical hurdles to a free election <p> By Ken OpaloUpdated Sat , May 21st 2016 at 00:00 GMT +3 <p> SHARE THIS ARTICLE <p> As I have argued in these pages before , the current impasse regarding the firing of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission commissioners is political . The commissioners ' reputation has been irreparably damaged by the Chickengate scandal . <p> In addition , the latest opinion polls show that large segments of the public -- on both sides of the political divide -- lack faith in the commissioners , and by extension the IEBC <p> Meanwhile , the country 's political leadership -- largely from the opposition , but also including some Jubilee politicians -- has voiced its desire to see the commission restructured . There is no doubt that majority of Kenyans want IEBC reformed . In the minds of most of them , that means firing the current commissioners . Chairman Issack Hassan and his team should do the honourable thing and resign . Kenyans have lost trust in them . <p> But the IEBC is more than just the commissioners . There is also the secretariat . While we might have @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ commissioners , we should not lose sight of the secretariat which needs to lay the groundwork for next year 's elections . <p> It needs to register voters and make sure all the logistical aspects of running a credible election are in place . <p> And herein lies some of the ways in which we should be trying to fix the IEBC . For now the focus has purely been on the political aspects of its operations -- largely on account of the complete lack of trust on the commissioners . <h> READ MORE <p> But focus should also be on the mechanical ways in which we can make next year 's election more credible . Part of the reason why the opposition lacks faith in the IEBC is because of alleged tampering with the vote count after the balloting was completed in 2013 and in the Kericho by-election . So how can we fix this ? If we are honest about wanting to conduct a credible presidential election in 2017 , here is what we should be investing in . <p> The IEBC will have roughly about 35,000 polling @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ be able to generate a similar number of data points that will contribute to its national tally . <p> How can we make these observations trustworthy ? <p> The IEBC should solicit for volunteers and agents from the political parties for each polling station . It should not be hard to come up with more than 35,000 volunteers on a public holiday . <p> Second , these volunteers and agents should be equipped with phones with which they can take pictures of the ballot boxes and the tallying process throughout polling day . <p> These pictures can then be transmitted over scheduled intervals to both party headquarters and the national tallying center . The same pictures would be time stamped and geo-tagged . <p> At the end of the day the volunteers and voters would transmit the final tally from each polling station directly to the different political parties and the national tallying center . 35,000 polling stations may sound like a lot , but consider the amount of money the government spends on pens , or the amount that is routinely lost to corrupt officials . <p> Furthermore , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ time on Election Day . The advantage would be to have 35,000 unique data points that are easily verifiable when arriving at the final count . Pulling this off is a logistical possibility , if we really want to do it . <p> In the same vein , we could invest in a parallel vote tallying system that to relay results to the public alongside the official channel . There should be no fear that the transmission of results will ignite violence . Kenyans are smarter than we often give them credit for . 
@@8943237 @ @ @ @ ... @ @ @ @ @ political extremists <p> By Henry MuneneUpdated Sat , May 21st 2016 at 00:00 GMT +3 <p> SHARE THIS ARTICLE <p> If there is one thing I came to learn early in life about human survival , it is the futility of fear . Fear changes nothing . It blows up mountains of strife out of molehills . Talking of the molehills and anthills of the Savannah , growing up in the African countryside means you must be courageous to survive . <p> At least that was the wisdom in our childhood days . You had to take every challenge to a totally unnecessary duel with feigned superciliousness ; otherwise you became the coward everyone sought out whenever they wanted to punch something . Looking tough , arrogant and unyielding was the done thing , even for closet cowards who ran for the hills whenever fists were clenched . <p> The wisdom of back then , unfortunately , might not hold today . After discovering Thomas Hobbes and Chinua Achebe , we came to learn that it is foolish to expect to live as a society for many years if everyone bared their chests and @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ reality that whenever society stops considering other perspectives , even when they differ with what you believe , we hark back to the law of the jungle where life is solitary and short . <p> It is not entirely unfamiliar , as we had a taste of it in 2008 . We also see it in many parts of the world every waking day . Which makes Achebe 's words brutally immortal : It is in the compound of the coward that we stand and watch the ruins of what used to be the courageous man 's house . <p> Now , looking at the furore surrounding the Opposition 's bid to oust the electoral agency , one can tell we are fast disregarding Achebe 's advice on strategic cowardice . The chests are all out . And so are the water canons , boots and canisters . <p> You do not need to ask an opposition adherent what they think of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission ( IEBC ) . They will tell you that the team is not independent and must go home . All of it @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ with the 2017 elections , but an anti-corruption matter after the Chickengate scandal . <h> READ MORE <p> They will tell you that they are exercising their constitutional right to protest and that the so-called alternative ways are non-existent of removing the IEBC team due to Jubilee 's tyranny of numbers in Parliament . They will also say Jubilee has brought back police brutality to suppress alternative views . They will even throw in the sovereignty of the people . <p> Now you also do n't need to mount any research to find out the Jubilee position . They will tell you that CORD should have looked for an alternative way of pushing out the IEBC team . That it wanted to use the failed push for the Okoa Kenya referendum to whip up euphoria for next year 's polls and are now fumbling for another strategy . That the police are under pressure to stop looting . They will also insist the anti-IEBC rallies have nothing to do with fighting graft and that CORD leaders have been selectively silent over allegations against some in their coalition . Then they @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ if you listen to the two sides in isolation , they make perfect sense . And unless a middle ground is sought , preferably mediated by level-headed guys with no direct stake in next year 's polls , the cancer of tribal hatred will continue to spread . It is quite troubling that both sides are warning that if the other side does not stop , and to quote one leader , " Kenya will never be the same again . " <p> My personal view is that no side should be allowed to clothe partisan agenda in national garb , to the extent of lighting a fire under the country , however progressive their propaganda might sound . This must be demanded of both sides because we are living in times when you can sit at home and decide what whole regions are likely to believe on national issues . <p> We must let reason prevail and not allow fear-mongering to whip us into the kind of tension that makes an otherwise harmless reptile to bite you . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ <p> The 23-year-old ,

It 's wrong to use our youths negatively instead of empowering them to change their lives positively , " he added . <p> Though Mr Maangi avoided saying his next course of action , he urged youths to be agents of change by shaming leaders who were out to taint images of other . <p> " We are blessed to have very brilliant youths @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ lose focus and remain poverty stricken for longer times . Time has come for them to change for the better , " Maangi added . <p> He urged area leaders to promote peace and morality within the society through community-based organisations .

@@9095236 <h> kenyans may be ... to the zika virus <h> Pages <p> Just days ago , the Zika virus strain responsible for the outbreaks in Brazil was detected in Africa for the first time . With more than 7,000 suspected cases of Zika in Cape Verde , the World Health Organisation said it was concerned that the latest strain was spreading and was " on the doorstep of Africa " . Our writer sat down with Dr Ahmed Kalebi , CEO of Lancet Laboratories East Africa and a consultant pathologist who spoke on what the outbreak could possibly mean for Kenyans . <p> We are seeing re-emergence of the Zika virus , many years after its discovery in 1947 . What kind of a virus is it ? <p> For a long time zika was relatively unknown . It was discovered in the Zika forest in Uganda . At that time , Yellow Fever was the big thing and researchers were working with animals in the Zika forest trying to understand the disease in the 1940s . They noticed that some monkeys would get a fever for a short time and then disappear . But when they injected the infected blood to rats , @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ this is a Neurotropic virus ( one capable of infecting nerve cell ) and started looking at it more closely . That was in 1947 . Later , the first case was reported in Uganda of someone infected with the zika virus . Samples were taken to CDC ( US Centre for Disease Control ) who were able to identify and match it to the same virus that was described in 1947 . <p> Some years later , another case was discovered in Polynesia ( Pacific region ) , and later in the Philippines and Americas . But the reality is that most likely , zika is all over in what we call the Sylvatic cycle ( occurring in or affecting wild animals ) . <p> How does it spread ? <p> It mainly circulates in the wild among monkeys and other animals in the forest , just like Ebola , which is mostly confined in animals like bats and monkeys . What happens is that through human contact with wildlife , you get this cycle that moves from wild to human -- the wild cycle - causing transmission . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ bites people during the day . <p> Do we have the aedes eagypti mosquito in Kenya ? <p> Yes . There are all over . It 's much more common than the malaria-causing mosquito . <p> How has the current outbreak evolved ? <p> Up until 2007 , there were less than 20 cases ever described in humans . Then in 2013 and 2014 , there was an outbreak in the Polynesia affecting more than 3,000 people . Even then , there was not so much outcry because people recovered and a few got the Guillain-Barr ? Syndrome ( GBS ) which causes nerve damage . Another subsequent outbreak occurred in South America in 2015 starting

@@9175239 <p> On the banks ... the Limpopo River near Musina , a team from the farming enterprise , ZZ2 , have completely remodelled , refurbished and extended an outdated tomato pack-house , in just over three months . <p> The upgraded pack-house forms part of a major infrastructure investment on the remote farm , Esme-four , with the goal of improving productivity and ensuring water security for tomato production . A new 1.3 million cubic metre water reservoir , Voorwaarts dam , is pivotal to this development program . The dam is used to store flood water from the Limpopo River in the rainy season to provide sufficient irrigation water throughout the production season . <p> Floodwater extraction from the Limpopo River <p> In the last quarter of 2015 , with the drought pressing , ZZ2 fast-tracked the completion of the pump systems to fill Voorwaarts dam . By January 2016 the infrastructure was in place , the dam filling up and with the drought at a critical level , ZZ2 could increase planned production on Esme-four by 60% . The decision to upgrade the pack-house earlier than anticipated was necessary to handle and protect the value of this increased volumes of tomatoes . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ had to be in operation when the first crops were to be harvested , which gave us three months to complete , ? says Ian van Brouwershaven , project leader from ZZ2 . <p> Remodelled packhouse employs 180 people <p> It involved reviewing the whole process , from delivery of the fruit from the fields to leaving the pack-house as a washed , sorted , packaged , refrigerated and marketable product . ? The remote location was a challenge . It is situated far from support services and just to communicate with the site was a challenge . We organised a capable team consisting of ZZ2 personnel and contractors to plan and execute the work , with permanent on ? site management supported by our whole organisation. ? <p> The pack-house was designed and built to the highest food safety requirements . ? BRC ( British Retail Consortium-global standard ) accreditation of the pack-house will start shortly , ? says Louis Pretorius , head of ZZ2 ? s pack-houses . <p> First day of packing tomatoes in Esm ? four packhouse <p> The loading zones were enlarged by 2200m2 to @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ in handling areas and existing water and electrical infrastructure were upgraded . A1725m2 expansion to the pack-house structure were built to accommodate new infeed , washing systems and new pack-lines . New staff facilities , storerooms and offices were added to help manage the pack-house . <p> ? It is ZZ2 ? s first fully temperature controlled tomato pack-house , ? says Ian . Thirty tonnes of tomatoes per hour are received and cooled to 16 ? C before packing . The facility can handle and cool up to 300 tonnes of tomatoes per day . ? Managing the temperature of the tomatoes as soon as possible after harvest is vital to ensure better shelf life , freshness and more customer value. ?

@@9305239 <h> Why you should save in your youth <h> Author <p> It is a common practice that after a long week at work , we take the weekend as a chance to party and spend our money . Youths all over will be spotted flocking the latest joints , ready to ' get down ' . The talk on Friday evenings revolves around where the party is at , and which joints are getting lit tonight . Well , all work without play makes Jack a dull boy , but sad case here is that these actions are being taken by people who have no savings , and therefore , no money . <p> You are only as rich as what you remain with after you have taken care of all your expenses . And you are only as wealthy as the assets you have after taking care of the liabilities . It is sad enough that the youth are spending a lot of money that we do n't have on things we do n't need , but worse is we are working so hard to get money so we can spend all of it at the coolest joint in town . Money comes @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ this is we put ourselves in a situation where we either constantly need to borrow money , or find quick means of making the cash , which may not be legal or safe . <p> Saving a significant part of what you earn not only gives you financial freedom and independence , but is also a sign of maturity . Living from hand to mouth is what we do when we are spending all that we get . <p> We make different earnings in a month , and so we can not have a standard amount that we should all save . However , you could adopt the 50-30-20 format . Fifty is for life expenses , put in food , transport , family , etc . Thirty is for your personal needs , put in a weekend out , lunch with friends , road trip down Lake Naivasha , etc . Then twenty percent is savings . This you do not touch . You can save more , but not less than this percentage of your salary . <p> Priority here should be on finding a balance between what @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ if the scale is heavier on the income side that expenses side . As young as we are , we should adopt a plan for ourselves , and follow through if we are to achieve our dreams . Financial security is vital to living a stress-free life . <p> This is a citizen journalism website . The views expressed here do represent that of the Standard Group Ltd . Read terms and Conditions ?

@@9463232 <p> Kenya is still ... at risk of the disease even though the last imported case from South Sudan was reported in 2005 in Turkana County . <p> Guinea worm is mainly caused through the consumption of water contaminated by the Cyclops , a vector for Guinea worm . <p> To accelerate the requirements for certification , Kenya launched a multi-media communication campaign dubbed " Look for the last Guinea worm " in August 2015 . <p> The campaign sought to create awareness amongst Kenyans about the disease to levels acceptable by WHO . <p> The requirements , according to WHO , include the maintenance of a standard disease surveillance system where a minimum of 85% of health facilities countrywide , including sub counties and counties , submit timely reports about the disease . <p> The other pre-conditions are that at least 50% of Kenyans and 70% of people in Turkana County know about Guinea worm and how to prevent it and that there is a Sh 100,000 reward for reporting a confirmed case . <p> People must also be able to identify the disease on a photograph and know how it is transmitted and that all health workers should be able to respond @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ case contained to prevent transmission . <p> " However , despite the various efforts to raise awareness in the country through these strategies , the Ministry has not been able to achieve a 50% level of awareness .

@@9637238 <p> An estimated 500,000 ... are employed by the industry , which generates 1.2 per cent of gross domestic product ( GDP ) . <p> But for Naivasha Maasai pastoralists , the push by big farming companies has not sparked opportunity but panic that their traditional semi-nomadic lifestyle could be at risk . <p> In many parts of East Africa , governments are pushing for pastoralist communities to switch to settled farming . <p> Supporters saying such a move will create better food security , curb conflict between herders and farmers , and free up land . <p> But critics say switching from pastoralism to settled farming could make communities less resilient to climate change . <p> The growth of cut flower farms has intensified competition for dwindling grazing land and vanishing water supplies for the herdsmen whose traditional grazing grounds between Lake Naivasha and Mount Longonot have shrunk as the industry has expanded . <p> There are fears that further land acquisition in the area , which already accounts for around 70 per cent of total floriculture production in Kenya , will erode their livelihoods . <p> Not all roses <p> The cut flower companies say they have acquired land from communities and @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ " Land grabbing by elite individuals and encroachment of the lake by floriculture farms has dispossessed us of our ancestral territories denying us access to the lake by blockading access route to the only water source , " Jackson Shaa , a community leader , told the Thomson Reuters Foundation . <p> Community leaders say the privatisation and subdivision of their ancestral lands threatens ancient pastoralist practices , endangering livestock production and ecological sustainability and eroding communal rights to land and natural resources . <p> While they accept that floriculture and linked investments might stimulate economic growth in the region , they fear reduced access to land will widen social inequalities and put their livelihoods at risk . <p> " We have had talks with the Lake Naivasha growers ' group on how to promote sustainable agricultural and pastoralist practices but we are yet to see meaningful results , " Shaa said .

When it is constitutional , then we will see no more strikes @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ would elicit complaints from other public servants , Mogaka defended his approach , insisting that he will also try to incorporate other civil servants and work closely with the Salaries and Remuneration Commission to determine acceptable salaries across the board . <p> " I know that if the plebiscite is all about teachers , then we are likely to hear complaints from other public servants . It 's not a big issue because I can meet with key stakeholders and see how possible to in cooperate other sectors . We do n't want to hear workers going for strikes over pay , " he said .

@@9965233 AfricaExploring opportunities in Africa , Asia and the world <p> This year will see the 6th edition of the PMA Fresh Connections in Southern Africa , the event will take place 17-18 August in Pretoria . <p> The event has changed considerably since the first year when it attracted 150 attendees and was over in a day . This year , 600 attendees are expected from 15+ countries , it is now a 2 day conference with an integrated expo . <p> " The event has really become an anchoring footprint for the Southern African fresh produce supply chain , " explains Richard Owen , Vice President of Global Business Development with PMA . <p> " The main purpose of the conference is to make sure business connections happen across the supply chain , to make sure the buyer and seller come together in a format which makes sense to them , be it a retailer looking for a new grower , a packaging company selling a product to a grower or retailer or wholesaler , a seed company selling to a farmer . We try to provide the atmosphere for all of that to happen . " <p> @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ and tells delegates about what is happening in the fresh produce industry , both in Africa and globally . That is why there is such a mix of speakers . Its all about new ideas and how Southern Africa is positioned in the marketplace and how can they learn from what is being done around the world . <p> The theme of the Fresh Connections is similar to previous years , " Taking Fresh to the Next Level " putting the spotlight on the Fresh Produce Industry and all the innovative and new opportunities which go with it . The objective of the conference and tradeshow objective is to continue to grow and from an educational point of view : How to reach and understand this growing consumer market in Africa ? How can people take advantage of this ? There will be speakers present with practical experience on this subject . <p> Access to buyers " Suppliers from developing countries in Africa can gain access to buyers at the PMA . " Many South African-headquartered retailers have stores in other African countries . For example , Shoprite has locations @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ " They are looking to source products locally as much as they can . At Fresh Connections people can also learn about innovative new technologies from around the world , packaging materials , seeds as well as consumer trends . We also have sessions built around how to access the African middle class which growing very quickly . " <p> AfricaExports from South Africa into African countries have seen an increase in recent years , none more than apples . 5 years ago only 4% of South African apples went into the African continent , now it is over 40% , making it the biggest export market for apples . There is also a potential for other South African products . <p> Six out of 10 of the world 's fastest growing cities are in Africa and South Africa is no longer the number one economy in Africa , it is now Nigeria , and Kenya is also a very fast growing economy and may overtake South Africa in the next few years . <p> When investing in a country the political situation is important , but according to Richard @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ You have political situations and currency . Political influences in a country can affect how long it takes to move produce across a border , which can be a problem when you are dealing with fresh produce . You ca n't plan for that , but one of the things Fresh Connections can do is help people share experiences , ' What do you do if you produce gets stopped at the border ? , How can you prepare for that ? Is there an alternative way to go to market ? Or can we work collectively to resolve some of these issues ? ' " <p> Global TrendsCEO Bryan Silbermann will be back again talking about the global trends he sees across the industry , together with Peter Arnold , Managing Director at Mass Fresh , ( the African arm of Walmart ) . Bryan will speak about what he sees from a global perspective and Peter will comment on the on Southern African market . <p> Dave Corsi , Vice President/Produce &amp; Floral , Wegmans , US , will also be giving a presentation . Wegmans is considered @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ of their innovative displays and pricing models . This should be well received especially with the exporters in South Africa who move products into the States . <p> AsiaThere will be a session concentrating on South East Asia - specifically India , Indonesia and Malaysia . There are many opportunities in those countries for exporters from South Africa . The session includes speakers who have experience growing and developing South African brands there . <p> Another session will be dedicated to China . People are experienced at reaching the 1st tier cities in China , but what happens when you need to move to the next frontier , tier 2 and tier 3 cities ? <p> Traditional marketsThere will various sessions on European markets . These will be integrated into several global presentations including that of Bryan Silbermann . Europe will also be integrated in sessions about technology and innovation . <p> LogisticsLogistics are a huge part in the success of growing markets in African and one session will focus wholly on logistics in Africa . In South Africa they are reinventing the wholesale markets to make sure they are able to compete with the retailers in terms of producers selling to them . @@9982232 <p> This year , ... grape exports from Australia have exceeded 100,000 tonnes for the first time and prices have spiked . According to the Australian Table Grape Association the 2015-16 table grape export season saw 108,594 tonnes exported and April recorded the highest single volume of Australian table grapes exported for any month at 32,587 tonnes . <p> Exports to Japan increased by 406 per cent on the previous year , making it the fourth-largest export market for Australian table grapes . <p> ATGA chief executive Jeff Scott said growth in the Jap ? anese market was projected to continue . <p> ? Experts believe Japan could easily become Aus ? tralia ? s second-biggest trading partner after China , ? Mr Scott said . ? It ? s important to note at this point that the Japanese fresh produce market has seen growth in only two categories ? table grapes and kiwifruit. ? <p> The combined volume for the China and Hong Kong markets was 513 per cent higher in comparison with last year , but the Hong Kong market alone had dropped by 56 per cent . <p> Indonesia was the second-largest destination after China and was up 34 per cent @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ tonnes to the end of May 2016 with an estimated value of $364 million , making it 32 per cent higher than the same time last season . <p> Mr Scott said achieving new access into high-value markets such as China , Japan and South Korea had given the table grape industry an export advantage over other Aus ? tralian fruit industries . <p> ? Product differentiation is the key for Australian table grape growers . Major comp ? etitors Chile , South Africa and Peru have significant production advantages with cheap labour and lower input costs , by which the average Aus ? tralian grower is unable to compete , ? he said . ? In order to command a premium price over the significant volumes being produced by Chile , the Australian grower must supply fruit with high sugar content , crisp berries and consistent bunch colour. ?

@@9982235 <p> China is widely ... as an untapped market for perishables , but in order to provide real opportunities for shippers , the country needs to upgrade its cold supply chain . <p> Increasing consumption of fruit and vegetables , dairy and meat in China , according to research from the Dutch agri-finance group Rabobank , ? is being driven by continued economic growth and urbanization. ? <p> Although China ? s economic growth rate is slower and becoming more balanced , the country ? s economy is nonetheless expected to grow by six percent to seven percent annually in the coming years . That growth , the Rabobank research indicates , ? will elevate a further 38 million households into the upper middle class. ? China ? s appetite for fruit and vegetables , dairy , and meat is expected to increase by 17 percent over the next decade . <p> The country ? s growing demand for fresh food offers huge opportunities for exporters of perishable foods , provided that China makes the required investments in transportation , storage , and distributions infrastructures , according to a Rabobank report . China ? s more affluent consumers are making fresh foods more common @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ in China , food and agribusinesses are searching for improvements in food safety , quality , and more efficient paths to the Chinese consumer . <p> ? Food safety remains one of the biggest concerns for the Chinese consumer , ? said Wilco Hendriks , CEO of Rabobank China . ? China is improving its own food safety and security , reducing food waste , lowering healthcare costs and seeking better overall health improvements of the Chinese population . To meet the changing consumer needs , China is also looking at investments in the infrastructure and logistics of food transportation flows across domestic and international land routes instead of sea shipping lanes. ? <p> Europe and the Netherlands in particular are major suppliers of food and agricultural products to China . Increasing prosperity and China ? s growing demand for fresh food offers huge opportunities for imports from European food industry , but also require huge investments in cold chain infrastructure .

@@9982237 <p> Summer was interrupted ... bad weather in central-southern Italy . Last weekend , temperatures have been exceptionally low , 10 ? C below the period average . <p> With the drop in temperatures , a Flash Storm brought the snow back on the Abruzzo mountains ( Gran Sasson and even Altopiano delle Rocche ) . Strong rain hit the Bari area , especially along the coast and in the Bisceglie , Giovinazzo , Molfetta , Ruvo di Puglia and Terlizzi area . Between 50 and 60 mm of rain fell in just a few hours , causing many problems . <p> Flooded melon fields . <p> Farm owner Michele Manicone explains that " our 3 hectare melon field was completely flooded ( see photo above ) and other crops were also partly damaged . Other sandy areas along the coast were spared . The rain started on the 15th and continued throughout 16th July . Other farms reported a lot of damage . My neighbour had just planted around four hectares of tomatoes and his fields are still under half a metre of water . " <p> Michele is hoping the state of natural disaster will be declared . " I would like @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ caused by the rain but rather by the poor management of the drainage canal , which has not been cleaned in 10 years . ? 200 thousand had been destined to the reparation of its margins a couple of years ago , but nothing happened . " <p> Flooded crops . <p> Manicone has been operating on open fields for four years and sells its products on the fresh market . " We produce melons , watermelons , tomatoes , peppers and aubergines . We also have a shop in Lido del Sole . We also produce Camone and chocolate-coloured tomatoes for direct sales . " <p> The company was also testing new tomato varieties . " We had planted around 10,000 plants , which were ready for harvesting , but everything has been destroyed . " <p> Elsewhere in Puglia ... Officials said the initiative would help reduce food waste for suppliers and provide a more affordable produce option in stores . Three- and five-pound bags of " I 'm Perfect " apples will be available in around 300 stores in Florida this week . Walmart earlier this year began selling misshapen potatoes under the Spuglies brand at select stores . @@9982239 <p> Robert van Ooijen ... ? Tomatoes are back where they started ? Confusing market situation for vegetables <p> The market situation for vegetables could currently be called ? confusing. ? ? One product is very expensive and the other very cheap . Especially outdoor products are expensive , because so many have been lost due to rain . Greenhouse vegetables are cheaper in general , because they have not been affected by the weather conditions , ? says Robert van Ooijen . ? Besides , with outdoor vegetables it depends on the product how quickly it recovers from the bad weather . The influence of the holidays is also felt. ? <p> Prices vary <p> ? Of the types of lettuce for example , Lollo Rosso and fris ? e lettuce are very expensive , but Lollo Bionda on the other hand is not very expensive at all . A large difference in price exists between small and large . Large green bell peppers ( 80ers ) are sold at around 80 cent , but 70ers have to settle for 50 cent less . Red bell peppers are now increasing . Last week , prices were at 1.20 , and now between 1.50 and 1.60 . Yellow bell peppers started high , but yesterday got stuck on 1.40 . ? <p> TomatoesTomatoes experienced a revival , but are now back where they started . ? Vine tomatoes were sold at almost 50 cent , but beefsteak tomatoes were only sold around 45 to 50 cent . Those are not good prices for cultivators. @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ 
@@9982240 <p> Back in February ... the European Commission dealt a blow to certain cranberry-based products that are marketed as a ? medical device . " Now cranberry marketers are in a conundrum , as the draft decision by the Commission does not answer the question how such products should be classified . <p> While cranberry products sold as a ? food supplement " remain on the market , European regulators have rejected claims that were submitted for approval to show the effects of cranberries on health , making it difficult to promote the fruit ? s benefits , regulatory experts said . <p> Cranberries have long been touted as aids in treating bladder or urinary tract infections . However , during evaluations in 2009 through 2011 and in 2013 , the European Food Safety Authority ( EFSA ) rejected various health claims for cranberries , noted Joris Geelen , a former Belgian regulator who is now a partner with Singapore-based Food Compliance International Pte . Ltd . <p> The developments , he explained , basically closed the road to marketing cranberries in food supplements and left marketers in pursuit of the route of ? least resistance . " <p> Enter the ? medical device @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ one of the advantages of being able to make statements that are not subject to a nutrition and health claims regulation adopted by the Commission , explained Nicolas Carbonnelle , a senior associate in Brussels , Belgium , with the law firm Bird &amp; Bird LLP . <p> ? While you can say , ? This medical device is good for alleviating pain related to urinary tract infection , ? " such a claim , if made in connection with a food supplement , would need to be approved by EFSA on the basis of scientific evidence , said Carbonnelle , whose law practice includes advising food and beverage companies . <p> ? They ( EFSA ) are very strict in approving the claims , " the lawyer said in a recent phone interview . <p> The EU ? s 28 member states have been asked to comment on the Commission ? s draft decision . The decision , if finalized , will force companies marketing cranberry-based products as a medical device to develop another strategy . @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ is no

PHOTO : COLLINS ODUOR/STANDARD <p> An uneasy calm has returned at the Nandi-Kisumu counties border that has experienced volatile clashes between two communities . Officers from the General Service Unit , regular police and anti-stock theft unit have also been deployed at the border . But even then , residents say there is still tension and a lasting solution is needed to end the inter-community clashes . <p> Since the violence started a few weeks ago , many families have been displaced , property including 45 hectares of sugarcane destroyed , schools closed , leaving about 7,000 pupils out of classes . <p> During recent meetings between the National Cohesion and Integration and Commission and members of the two communities , cattle rustling and stock theft were cited as major causes of the conflict . <p> " If cattle rustling is the root cause of our animosity towards each other , let the law deal with the suspects . Chiefs have also been challenged to be vigilant in intelligence gathering and sharing . <p> " Chiefs in the warring areas are required to assist police gather intelligence to ensure arrest of all suspected rustlers , " he said . <p> As part of the peace initiatives , Kisumu Governor Jack Ranguma has also formed a five-member team comprising church leaders , teachers and members of the community . The team will report back to him in two weeks with a detailed report . <p> Raguma said the findings of the committee 's report will inform how he will work with his Nandi County counterpart Cleophas Lagat in their efforts to find a lasting solution to the conflict . <p> As voices of reason try to find a lasting solution to the problem , the blame game continues . @@10092235 <h> Tanzania will fare better with a less rigid work permit policy <p> Kenya National Chamber of Commerce and Industry chairman Kiprono Kittony <p> Recently , Tanzania President John Pombe-Magufuli ordered foreigners , particularly those without work permits , to surrender their jobs to locals pronto . This hard-hitting edict is a direct consequence of the Non-Citizens ( Employment Regulations ) Act , passed by Tanzania 's Parliament during its April - June 2015 session . The Act tightened rules for subsidiaries of multinational companies operating in Tanzania intent on recruiting expatriate employees . The hope is that showing foreigners the door would automatically pave the way for employment of Tanzanian youth . While it is the duty of the state to secure and protect the livelihoods of its citizens , the sweeping , if punitive , action heralded by the presidential diktat determined to show foreigners working in Tanzania the door enmass is regrettable . In fact , I highly doubt that such a decision would serve the best interests of any of the East African Community member countries let alone Tanzania 's . <p> Well , nationalism propped on simplistic populism may register transient dividends for demagogic leaders but not for long-term @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ aiming at closer integration and synergetic existence . Ultimately , it remains Tanzania 's sovereign right to make policies that serve the interests of her citizens best . Whichever way you view it , President Magufuli is well within his powers to make decisions that promote the welfare of his countrymen and women . At the same time , Tanzania 's resources and economy must serve its nationals before they benefit foreigners . <p> However , 21st Century statecraft and international relations calls for more sacrifices and concessions rather than knee-jerk or populist retorts . On this subject , Paddy Ashdown , a British politician once famously declared that , symptoms of decline in nations as in humans are ; scleroticism , institutional arthritis and resistance to change -- proposed a route to the cordial coexistence among states . He forewarned in his 2009 presentation titled " The end of western hegemony " that triumphs in a world overtaken by a myriad insecurities , will take greater tolerance among nations that do not share the same culture , history , worldview or even values . <p> In the case of @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ said that Tanzania , with regard to culture , history , worldview and values is dramatically different from other EAC members . In fact , the challenges faced by ordinary citizens across the EAC region are very much similar . <p> Kenya and Tanzania have made much headway in economic integration that can not just be pulverized by cavalier political decrees . <p> It is important for Tanzania 's leadership to come to terms with the fact nationals of the two countries have devised organic ways and means of enhancing their own cooperation away from officialdom . Like Kenyans , many of Tanzania 's business people have sidestepped bureaucratic inertia to create a thriving business regime . Most of the oranges and the " not to miss " cooking ingredient , tomatoes , in Nairobi today are from Tanzania . If indeed the leadership of the two countries and other EAC member states are true servants of the people , they should be enhancing rather than curtailing such integration . <p> The scheduled march to a fully integrated East Africa has been arduous and winding . With occasional dissenting voices @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ no longer easy to convince anyone that the integration of East Africa into an economic bloc is a universal tenet desired by the leadership of all the member states . It is indeed in the interest of Tanzania and other EAC member states to enhance , rather than downgrade regional integration .

The Orange Democratic Movement intends to sue the Independent Electoral Boundaries Commission if it fails to register anybody in the country as a voter . Photo : JAMES OMORO/Standard <p> A number of ODM legislators led by party chairman John Mbadi argued that the Independent Electoral Boundaries Commission ( IEBC ) had not given clear guidelines on how Kenyans living in foreign counties will be registered for voting . <p> The legislators said the IEBC may use the process to register voters in the US with the Jubilee supporters , hence ignoring their counterparts from the Opposition strongholds .

@@10117239 <p> A man accused of murdering his wife and child who on Monday told a Nakuru High Court that his life is in danger while out on bond has been remanded at Nakuru G.K Prison . <p> Jeremiah Ngware was accused of murdering his wife Grace Wacheke and his son Brian Ngware on the morning of June 17 , 2010 at Falling Waters Secondary School in Nyahururu . <p> He told Nakuru Resident Judge Maureen Odero that his life was in danger because he received threatening calls and messages from people who claimed to be victims ' relatives saying that they will be happy to see him dead . <p> " I received numerous threatening texts and calls saying that they will be relaxed when they see me dead and this has unsettled me as I keep hiding , " he said . <p> His lawyer David Mongeri told the court that his client believes that he may be safer in custody pending determination of his case . <p> His case has seen two witnesses testifying against him and further eight yet to testify , including two of his children who were at the scene of crime . <p> Ngware , a former prison @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Secondary School deputy head teacher in Nyahururu is said to have had a series of mental illness before he allegedly committed the crime . <p> According to a psychiatric report by Dr Joseph Njau of Rift Valley Provincial General Hospital in Nakuru , Ngware was mentally unsound thus he could not be ready to proceed with the proceedings of the court . <p> The doctor recommended that he requires intensive treatment under a psychiatrist before he pleaded to the charges . <p> He pleaded not guilty to the charges of murder and was released on a surety bond of Sh100,000 and one surety who was his brother . <p> According to the witnesses ' testimonies in a court file , they claimed that the accused assaulted the wife and the boy at his home causing severe head injuries . <p> Judge Odero ordered that the accused be remanded at the prison while his lawyer follows up at the C.I.D offices about the threats .

PHOTO : Agencies <p> London , Sunday <p> As he made his way , slowly , to the touchline the derision filled the night air . Then the response from blue corner . " Diego Costa -- he 's done it again " . And he had . Drawn the red card , got the goal , got right up Arsenal 's hooter . It was just like old times . <p> The result was familiar , too . A Chelsea win . These teams have met 27 times competitively in 12 seasons and this was Chelsea 's 16th win , with seven draws . <p> The last 12 goals , in league fixtures , have belonged to Chelsea too . Do Arsenal have the nerve to win the title this season ? They certainly do n't have the steel to beat Chelsea . <p> Not many teams will drop six points to them this season , but Arsenal have . And while they curse bad luck and Costa 's dark side for the @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ home team here . <p> Per Mertesacker made a dreadful decision leading to his dismissal and Arsenal barely managed a shot at goal . Cesc Fabregas ran the game in midfield , aided as ever by the tireless , Willian and was unfortunate not to win a penalty when bodychecked by Laurent Koscielny after a beautiful run in the second half . <p> Nemanja Matic gave away a foul , and was booked , for an identical challenge on Alexis Sanchez in midfield soon after shows the inconsistency . <p> True , Arsenal were down to 10 for 71 minutes of the match but , even handicapped , they knew what they had to do after half-time and disappointed . <p> Their best chances were scrappy , scrambles with opportunity coming by fortuitous deflection rather than invention . Leicester will have looked at this with quiet satisfaction . Everyone thought they would be the ones that blinked first . <p> Petr Cech is the best goalkeeper around these parts since David Seaman . So , knowing that , why did n't Per Mertesacker trust him to deal with Diego Costa @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ lovely pass put Costa through after 19 minutes , Mertesacker 's lack of pace left him floundering . <p> At that point , he had a choice . Lunge , risk missing his tackle , and play the inevitable game of red card roulette , or chase Costa , applying as much pressure as possible and hope that Cech can do the rest . -Dailymail

@@10329237 <h> Ford F150 Raptor : The Age of the Pick-up is upon us ! <h> share <p> On my bucket list there 's a list of places I would like to visit , with Germany occupying pride of place at the very top . <p> It is , without doubt , the promised land for all motoring enthusiasts and I have often dreamt of maxing out a rented supercar on the Autobahn ; Germany 's public road network that for the most part have no speed limits and strangely , lower fatal car accidents than , say , America 's highways . <p> To drive the Nurburgring , the almost mythical Green Hell , a race track that has crushed both bones and egos of the best drivers in the world and of course visit the Mercedes-Benz Museum where the entire history of the oldest car company is meticulously spread out for your viewing pleasure . <p> One country that has never crossed my mind is the aforementioned US of A. Mostly it is because I distrust their food . I hate their version of English and the fact that their culture as a whole is determined by Hollywood . And when it comes @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ , but better . <p> That is apart from Pick-ups , or pick-up trucks , as they like to call them . <p> Kenyans dominate the running scene , Brazil owns football and Americans have the pick-up game down to a science : they practically invented them . <p> A long time ago when people were more creative , car companies could either sell you a complete car or just the chassis and you would get to complete the rest of the car with the help of a coach-building company . This led to some very innovative designs and some pretty impressive one-off masterpieces . <p> For the common mwananchi , it led to the birth of the pick-up when a coachbuilder , the Galion Allsteel Body Company , took a Ford Model T chassis and basically fit a box on it to carry merchandise around . <p> It was such a success that Ford started making them and Dodge came in for a share of the pie . In over one hundred years this has evolved into a very lucrative segment whose mascot is the maddest pick up ever @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ that takes steroids and cocaine and you 'd be right on the money . It 's bigger than a Range Rover and the sound coming from the tailpipes is an aural middle finger to environmentalists . It 's probably the manliest car out there . <p> Yes , the Mercedes G6x6 is better but the badge compared to the Raptor 's blue oval is a bit bourgeois . The Raptor is like a sun-scorched farmer with an axe , which he uses to trim his fingernails . <p> Behind the Ford emblem you will find a 3.5 litre V6 engine assisted by two turbochargers to churn out a healthy 450 horsepower to all four wheels . A terrain response function means that it adjusts to pulverize anything mother nature throws in its wake with a 10 speed automatic to take care of proceedings . <p> The frame has been optimised for hooning , which is to say that you can drive it like a drunk monkey and it will take the abuse you throw at it . @@10341235 <h> New Sh12m AI services turn around dairy farming <p> A calf named after Elgeyo Marakwet Governor Alex Tolgos , one of the prodcuts of AI . PHOTOS:JAMES WANZALA/STANDARD <p> The Elgeyo Marakwet County Government has made strides in improving fortunes of dairy farmers through provision of subsidised Artificial Insemination ( AI ) services . <p> So far , the county 's Department of Agriculture has carried out AI in over 7,000 cattle , with over 1,000 cows having calved in the two-year-old programme aimed at improving cattle breeds for increased milk production . <p> The Executive in-charge of Agriculture Shadrach Yatich said given the cheap cost , demand for AI services has grown exponentially . <p> " We procured semen for farmers and sold it to them at Sh200 , down from the market rate of Sh2,000 . As for the sexed semen , they pay only Sh500 , down from Sh6,000 , the prevailing price , " he said . <p> The purchase has resulted into more than 1,033 calves two years later , since the Sh12 million project was launched . Joseph Kwambai , a farmer from Kapchemutwa , Keiyo North Sub-county is one of the beneficiaries who bought sexed semen @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ I had a bull that I used on my cows because of the high cost of AI . Every time my cows calved , they gave birth to bulls only . The bull eventually became old without giving me any female cow , " says Mr Kwambai . <p> That was not enough ; Kwambai says the cow only produced a paltry 10 litres of milk , which did not earn him much . " But with the County Government 's introduction of pedigree semen , I am a happy farmer because I have my first calve , a female , " said Kwambai . <p> Yatich says that the county went on to employ AI inseminators , purchased motorbikes for them and sent them to the wards to serve farmers at no cost . <p> He said this had given farmers an opportunity to go for AI services that were previously the preserve of well-to-do large scale dairy farmers . <p> Mary Kipkosgey , 50 , even named her calf after Governor Tolgos , to appreciate the service . " I want it to be remembered by future generations @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ Kipkosgey . The project , she says is good , because it makes the calves grow faster and with good weight , thus enabling it produce more milk , as opposed to conventional calves . <p> She urges the County Government to create awareness of the project , since many do not know about it . I also encourage jobless youth to embark on dairy farming using AI , since it will bring them quick money . <p> The cheap AI services were among the governor 's flagship projects in his pre-election manifesto . The executive said the programme 's success rate was encouraging , and the county was now taking a step further in helping farmers adopt modern animal husbandry methods . 
@@10341237 <h> Our Judiciary must reclaim the respect it once enjoyed <p> The death of US Supreme Court judge Antonin Scalia this week has made me reflect on the role of the Judiciary generally but more particularly , that of the Supreme Court in contested democracies like ours . In the US , the Supreme Court is such a pre-eminent institution , that the question of the appointment of Justice Scalia 's replacement is now the most critical issue defining the race between the Republicans and Democrats . Our Constitution assumed that the Kenyan equivalent would play the same role that the US Supreme Court and indeed other similar courts play in resolving deeply contentious political and social issues . <p> It is for this reason that the Court was allowed by the Constitution to handle only those matters serious enough to have national interest consequences including those revolving around critical constitutional questions . Similarly , both in letter and spirit the Court was supposed to comprise Kenya 's best jurists with unquestionable integrity who would earn the people 's trust . In an ideal world the Court would have grown in credibility and earned the trust of Kenyans before it adjudicated severely contested issues @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ test was the Presidential election petition which in a place like Kenya where everything is seen through politically biased lenses left it grievously wounded . It did not help that due to constitutional timelines and its own positivistic approach to resolving procedural issues , some protagonists were left with a credible peg to hang their grievances on ; in their view , the Court had sacrificed substance for form in rejecting evidence presented after the procedural timelines . The injury to the Court 's reputation suffered some more when it entered into the fray of other election petitions . It is clear from a literal reading of the Constitution that it was never intended for the Court to resolve election petitions as a standard appellate court . But because the Constitution allowed the Court to resolve " issues arising out other interpretation of the Constitution " appellants were able to frame every petition in terms that raised constitutional interpretation issues . <p> The problem with election petitions is that like elections , they thrive in the realm of " murky extremis " and anyone who wrestles in that arena stands @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ the Court actually produced some good jurisprudence in the election petitions , but because of the murkiness of political contests , the grime that has arisen in the Kidero petition may , unless well handled , sound the death knell of the young court . If the Court , is to survive and retain its place in the pinnacle of Kenya 's democratic institutions , it must resolve the Tunoi matter expeditiously and credibly . <p> Firstly , I would encourage Justice Tunoi to face the tribunal if indeed the allegations are false . The culture of assuming that allegations mean guilt must not be allowed to grow . If he does , then who sits in the tribunal is critical . They must not be people clearly aligned with political players as happened the last time a tribunal was appointed . I would expect to have the likes of Nzamba Kitonga SC and similar credible jurists , including one or two from outside Kenya . I am aware the Constitution does not expressly anticipate appointment of non-Kenyans other than for a tribunal for the Chief Justice but neither is @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ move expeditiously and not allow itself to be an arena for cheap grandstanding . It must be about credible facts . Thirdly , the process must be open . Granted this may bring out some painful public linen washing , but it may be the only way to exorcise any demons that many haunt the court in future . If however the Judge chooses not to appear before the tribunal , the JSC must find ways to lay to sleep the implicit allegations against the other Judges . If that does not happen , the whiff of suspicion against the Court will so damage it that the Country will pay a heavy price especially when the Court must still resolve future Presidential petitions . 
@@10341239 <h> How skewed KRA management structure is limiting effectiveness <p> Kenya Revenue Authority ( KRA ) was once an enviable institution . It had the most attractive and desired working environment in public service . It executed its core mandate of revenue collection effectively , and with integrity . Staff operated professionally in assessment of taxes . The institution embraced best management practices in tax administration . It earned a regional recognition as the leader in revenue collection . <p> KRA today is a pale shadow of itself . The days of glory are gone . Staff are demoralised as the institution sags under the weight of nepotism and cronyism . Staff misconduct and corruption have seized KRA and eroded its professionalism . <p> Diverted imported goods and dumped transit stuff have flooded the markets and paralysed local industry , usually with involvement of KRA staff . It is no longer a stickler to rules , and flouts its regulations and laws to execute public relations stunts . Incompetent managers have been placed in offices to the chagrin of competent ones who feel demotivated by the unprocedural actions . <p> For the six months to December 2015 , KRA has announced it performed dismally @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ are concerns that by June 2016 year end , it could be off target by as much as Sh100 billion . This is in spite of the huge growth in imports which is a major revenue source , and a 5.8 per cent growth in the economy last year . Of the Sh48 billion shortfall , Sh16 billion relates to decrease in VAT on imports . KRA at Mombasa Port that is the main imports entry is rotten to the core . Last year , Parliament enacted new excise laws that brought in more taxes on cars , water , juices etc. , in order to expand the tax base . <p> In recent years , KRA had invested billions of shillings in modernisation and ICT to boost its capability . For instance , it is installing a controversial $10 million Integrated Customs Management System to replace the Simba system . A new Cargo Management System , complete with cargo scanners and truck monitoring systems for transit goods were adopted . A modern iTax online system for filing tax returns was also installed . <p> But all these appear not @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ county governments catalysed enhanced collections in the regions as KRA fails to partner with the counties to position itself . <p> Incompetent management bedevils KRA . The Commissioner General who runs the outfit is probably the most listless leader the organisation has had since its inception . He was upgraded from the large taxpayers department to the office by the board under undue pressure . The renewal of his term too was not formally gazetted and it is unclear for how long he will continue to be at the helm . <p> The vesting of absolute powers under his office , away from the respective commissioners of VAT , income tax and other revenue resources significantly altered the management landscape in the organisation . <p> Commissioners no longer have the power to act independently and promptly on matters under their docket without his endorsement . Globally , the best practice is for the tax commissioners to decide on matters of taxes , which is a specialised role . <p> Treasury should weigh in on the board and rectify the institutional morass before it gets worse . It should also review @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ tax commissioners . The threat of lifestyle audits and vetting of staff alone will not redeem the rot in this organisation without undertaking structural and top management changes . 
@@10341240 <h> Uganda must embrace a fair electoral process <p> Even before Yoweri Museveni had been declared President , observers of the Ugandan elections were unequivocal . They concluded that the process was unfair , lacked credibility and was marked by irregularities . <p> But this deduction had been expected after the main opposition candidate Kizza Besigye was arrested three times as the tallying was going on . According to the 13-nation Commonwealth Observer Group led by former Nigerian President Olusegun Obasanjo , voter bribery and the misuse of state resources undermined the electoral process . The observers also raised issues about the competence , credibility and ability of the Electoral Commission to conduct fair elections and were particularly unhappy with the delays of supply of voting material to polling stations , particularly in Kampala . <p> Yet such election infractions are common in Africa . By and large , most African countries have made a transition where there are cyclical elections that pave way for grassroots and nationals leaders to be elected to form representative governments under the duly elected head of state . However , even though these elections are held within legally-prescribed intervals , some of these elections -- like the Ugandan @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ times violence has resulted when the outcome has been disputed , and Kenyans are only too familiar with such consequences from the lessons learnt in 2007/2008 . After more than 1,000 deaths in Kenya 's 2007 General Election , recommendations for electoral reforms have largely been implemented , but mischief and mutual suspicion of the protagonists is undiminished . <p> It is not just elections that invite violence as recent events in Burundi demonstrated . Here the controversy over President Pierre Nkurunziza 's term limit led to an abortive coup d'etat and sporadic killings as the Bujumbura government cracked down on demonstrators . <p> Africa is replete with such examples . Yet the continent provided one of the best examples of a leader who readily gave up power so that others could carry the leadership mantle . Nelson Mandela resisted pressure to run for a second term and graciously allowed others to take over after being elected as the first black president in post-Apartheid South Africa . <p> African leaders must borrow from this legacy to create democratic institutions . History has demonstrated that leaders who hold on to power @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ do a great disservice to those they govern . 
@@10347230 to 15 Cents Per Gallon <p> An air of concern and caution hung in the air as the price of gasoline increased on Friday in Venezuela to 15 cents per gallon , which is hardly anything in many other countries , but startling to those in the oil each country that is financially beaten . <p> The gasoline price had previously been less than one tenth of a penny a gallon the prior day and history showed how abruptly the mood in Venezuela could shift when gasoline is adjusted up . <p> Over 1,000 people were killed during a 1980s weeklong riot when the government tried to increase prices . <p> However , this time Venezuelans appeared stoic as the price was increased earlier during the week in an announcement by Nicolas Maduro the Venezuelan President . <p> Even with the new increase , gas in Venezuela remains the worlds cheapest . <p> One operator of a state-owned service station in the poor section of Caracas in which riots started in the 1980s said that motorists were acting normal and nothing out of the ordinary happened . <p> Many people in the oil rich country believe that inexpensive gasoline @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ increase gasoline prices touched off a number of hikes in bus fares and in turn provoked the riots known as Caracazo that left up to 1,200 dead . <p> Fearful of violence again , the government had raised the price just once since , keeping it the same since 1994 . <p> However , the subsidy had turned out very costly . The PDVSA oil company , which is state-owned , estimates that artificially inexpensive gasoline was costing the Venezuelan government approximately $12 billion annually . <p> The increase in price should reduce the subsidy from the government by only $2 billion , a savings it will apply to importing additional food , said Maduro . <p> Scarcities of food have forced Venezuelans to wait in line for hours to buy their groceries . <p> The increase in gas price was one part of a number of adjustments announced by Maduro on Wednesday of last week in an attempt to ease the severe economic crisis in the country . <p> The economy in 2015 shrank 5.7% said the central bank , while inflation is the highest in the world at @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @ @
